title: 7 Things You Might Not Know About Driving A Tesla
description: Since youre alive and breathing in 2018, you probably know about Tesla  both because of its efforts to revolutionize the auto industry with its electric cars, and  the sometimes-catastrophic results when those efforts go awry. As MrMobile Ive driven the Tesla Model S, Tesla Model X, and the new Tesla Model 3  but those videos only gave me a chance to give you the 10,000-foot view of each car. This time, I want to talk about the little things: from the pleasures to the pitfalls. Im Michael Fisher and these are 7 things you might not know about driving a Tesla.    [SPONSOR]  This video was made possible by a Tesla Model S P100D loan from TeslaRents.com. Visit TeslaRents and use code "MOBILE" for $25 off your next rental of the P100D "Supercar" or the Tesla 70D!    [LINKS]  Wired article on EPA per-state efficiency for EVs:    [SUBSCRIBE TO MRMOBILE]     [ABOUT THIS VIDEO]  MrMobile's Driving A Tesla video was produced following several test drives in the Tesla Model X, Tesla Model 3 and two trims of Tesla Model S (P100D and P90D) in Massachusetts and Florida, totaling approximately one week of driving time across two years.     [MUSIC]  Burning Man" by Zac Nelson, available at Premium Beat:   Chill Waves by Roommate, available at Premium Beat:   Lets Get It by Eternity Bro, available at Premium Beat:   Tidal Lines by Ryan Carlson, available at Premium Beat:    [SOCIALIZE]        [DISCLOSURE]  This post may contain affiliate links. See Mobile Nations' disclosure policy for more details:
transcript: - [Michael Fisher] Since you are alive and breathing in 2018 you probably know about Tesla. Both because of its efforts to revolutionize the auto industry with its electric cars. And the catastrophic results when that revolutionization goes awry. Well as Mr. Mobile, I've drive the Tesla Model S, Model X, and the new Model Three but those videos only gave me a chance to give you the 10,000 foot view of each car. This time, I want to talk about the little things. From the pleasures to the pitfalls. I'm Michael Fisher and these are seven things you might not know about Driving a Tesla. (reflective techno music) For some of the driving in this video, I went hard core with a monster Model S P100D. I'll explain what those numbers mean in a second but it's basically the baddest Tesla you can buy short of a roadster. I rented it from teslarents.com. And if you live anywhere near Boston you can rent this same car, or the 70 D at the same website. A warm thank you to Tesla Rents for the loan that made this video possible. I wanna reverse my usual habit and start with some of the pain points. You see, Tesla has this kind of mystique around it. Kind of like Apple does. And while it's not entirely undeserved. Well, let's just say park a Tesla under a tree and it'll get just as dirty as an old LeBaron will. So number seven. Tesla's are high tech cars, and high tech anything can have bugs. I'm talking about stuff like the backup camera sometimes refusing to open when I put the car in reverse. I'm talking about the auto parking feature just not working a lot of the time in the Model Three even in ideal conditions. And less a bug than just an annoyance even in this crazy futuristic car the USB ports still only kick out enough power to charge your phone at a trickle. C'mon guys. The upside? The first two can be corrected with software updates. And just like your smartphone, Teslas get those over the air pretty regularly. Also just like your smartphone, a Tesla can be rebooted just by pressing and holding the steering wheel joysticks. Just be sure to clean your screen off before you do it. 'Cause uh, gross. Number six. Driving a Tesla feels like driving any other car except for a couple tiny little things. First off, when you're in gear in a regular gas burning automatic and you let your foot off the break the car will creep forward. By default, a Tesla will not. It'll just sit there until you press the accelerator. Well fortunately for creeps like me there's an option for this in the software. Enable it and the car will advance slowly forward at idle speed. Second, Teslas don't break the same. Whenever you let your foot of the go pedal at speed the electric motors essentially reverse roles to become generators recapturing some of your inertial energy and putting it back into the battery. That slows a Tesla much more quickly than a typical car. But it extends your range and also saves wear and tear on the brakes. Other EVs do this, too. Chevy calls it one pedal driving. Once you get used to it, it is a much more efficient way to drive than by bouncing your foot between pedals all the time. Number five. Acceleration isn't just for jerk bags. See, even the most conservative Tesla has more get up and go than you'll have ever have felt behind the wheel of a regular car. And this P100D, well, - Here we go. Whoa! - Oh (beep)! (laughs) - Whoa. - Oh my God. - [Michael] But the thing is footage like this tends to emphasize all the wrong aspects of power. You know, that it's only useful for drag racing. Used properly, acceleration is safety. In a Tesla, you never wonder if you're gonna have the speed to merge safely. You never have to put pedal to the metal and wait for the shifting of gears to let you pass by that big truck. My friend Crackberry Kevin has owned a Model S for years and he says it's that instantly available torque more than anything else that's likely to keep him a Tesla driver. Speaking of power, here comes number four. There's a lot you can tell about a Tesla just by looking at that number on the back. Take this P100D. The number represents the nominal battery capacity. In this case, 100 kilowatt hours. The P indicate the car has the performance package with a larger main motor for more go fast. And the D suffix tells you it's a galaxy class starship. The fifth to carry the name Enterprise. (disc scratching) Oh, wait. No. It tells you the car has dual motors. One driving the fronts and one for the rear ones. Finally, if there's an underline, it means the car you're looking at has ludicrous mode. Aka, enough acceleration to turn you into chunky salsa. Number three. Autopilot is terribly named. This combination of adaptive cruise control and automatic lane keeping blew me away when I first tried it in 2016. Yes, the car will drive itself, and yes, it's pretty good at it. But it still can't tell a traffic light from a tree. Nor will it stop for a stop sign. Nor will it save you from a collision in all circumstances. This is why Tesla's always insists you pay attention to the road even under autopilot. And the car confirms every few moments that you're keeping your hands on the wheel. It can tell. If you don't, it'll disable the feature for the rest of your drive. That's a great safety measure but it doesn't stop people from routinely overestimating the car's abilities. Bottom line, autopilot is no where close to being a fully self-driving solution, so it shouldn't carry a name that implies that it is. Hitting the home stretch with number two. Teslas do indeed work in the winter time. See most of the Tesla owning mobile nations team lives in colder climes. Derek, the Tessler Kessler, in Ohio and the aforementioned Crackberry Kevin in Winnepeg. We all have nicknames because we're all adults. Kevin parks his Model S outside in minus 30 degree temperatures. But he uses the remote preheating function so he never gets into a cold Tesla. But you may be saying, most batteries aren't very happy at very cold temperatures, so how does this battery-driven car perform after it's been in the deep freeze of a Chicago winter overnight? Well, as this helpful blog post points out, you can hope into a frozen Tesla and take off, no problem. But you will lose performance and range. I've seen reports of up to 40% temporary range reduction in cold weather. This is a problem all EB's have to contend with. And another important thing to note, you won't have regenerative braking until the battery warms up since charging a cold battery can damage the cells. Remember, regenerative braking is just recharging the battery with the motors. This helps explain why I see a lot more Teslas in Florida, than in Boston. The number one thing you might not know about driving a Tesla also applies to any electric vehicle. If you're an American buying an EV because you want to be more environmentally-conscious, you've probably wondered just how green you're being. If the power you use to charge that car comes from, say, coal or gas power plants. Well, according to this excellent article in Wired, the answer varies depending on where you reside. If you live in, say, Missouri, driving an electric vehicle does as much damage to the environment as does a gas car that gets 39 miles a gallon because Missouri gets most of its power from coal. If you live in California, which will generate half of its power through renewables by 2020, driving an EV is like driving a car that gets 109 miles per gallon. And as the country as a whole moves away from fossil fuels over time, electric vehicles on the whole get cleaner, which doesn't happen with gas-burning cars. Now, these cars are not 100% clean by any means. There are other issues to consider when it comes to battery sourcing and recycling. I'll have to cover that in a separate piece. If you're interested, let me know in the comments, and please subscribe so you don't miss future videos. Before you go scampering off, I've got a bonus fact for you, which also relates to charging. See, it pays to stick around to the end. You probably know that a Tesla super charger is like a gas station just for Teslas. Tops them up much faster than a regular charging station will. But did you know that your charging speed actually depends on which space you choose? See, each stall is numbered and each pair of stalls shares a transformer. So for the fastest charging on the go, pick a super charger where both of the pair are unoccupied. If you can. That tip from Derek Kessler, one more thanks to him, to Kevin Michaluk and of course, to telsarents.com for the time behind the wheel in this ridiculous P100D. Thanks for sticking with me through this longer form than usual video. Please leave your own Tesla tips and questions down in the comments. Until next time. Thanks for watching and stay mobile my friends.
